title: What are the essential life skills a 17-year-old should have? - Quora

response.answer_text: Lots of good answers on here already, but I’ll try to give you a few that your 20–21 year old self should definitely appreciate, seeing as my current self would have appreciated that advice. First, household and daily stuff. And that means more than doing your bed and taking out the trash. I come from a country that is labor intensive, we have people come over and wash our dishes and clean our floors, as such I grew up not knowing how to use a washing machine or how to fix minor problems in household life that could very easily be fixed. At 17, you might possibly be contemplating moving out for college in a year’s time. It’s the perfect time to learn small and handy things that we just rely on our parents or siblings to do. Learn to sow (no, I’m serious), at least minor tears, learn to deal with electric and electronic items (I’m not saying become a technician or something, but at least have a working knowledge of how to fix stuff), learn (or improve) your driving skills (I still can’t drive and I regret it). Second, cook. This has already been mentioned before by others, but please, please learn to cook your own food. It is so helpful for you when you’re living on your own. I understand not everyone may enjoy cooking to the same degree I do, but at least learn to make something simple and don’t rely on cup noodles all the time as some have the tendency to do. Third, learn to be mature. I might get some disagreements on this, but I’ve seen a general perception in some societies where it’s almost expected for teen boys and girls to be absolute assholes, where the excuse given is, “Oh, s/he’s just a kid, s/he’ll grow out of it”. I know this isn’t everyone, but it’s quite a few people from what I see. Don’t fall in with that. The years you have from 17 onwards are going to be the years you remember even when you’re 45 and have a very different life. Don’t do stupid stuff, have common sense, don’t be afraid to do things that make you happy, don’t fall into things just because your friends or those you want to become your friends are doing it. Fourth, develop communication and people skills. By 17, it’s possible that you already do, if maybe you work part time somewhere. But learn people skills, how to network, how to socialize professionally and formally. For a recluse like myself this stuff sounds awful, but in most professional fields these days, these skills often matter as much as, if not more than your grades and degrees. Fifth, critical thinking (and critical judgement). As a teen, I often thought this was stupid, or that was so dumb and so on and so forth. That is not critical thinking, learn to question what your parents are saying but don’t just be like, ‘Mom doesn’t understand me’ or ‘Dad is so dumb’. Try to look at things from other people’s perspectives, and understand them, and then make a decision. You’ll be entering a phase of life soon where there won’t be parents or school teachers to spoon feed things to you, you’ll have to take decisions for yourself, and it’s easy to let that get to your head. Think calmly (and coldly) about things, weight stuff against each other and then take decisions, whether it’s something like which college (or any) you want to go to, or even if you want to dye your hair hot pink. …and finally Responsibility. As a 17 year old, you’re at a threshold between adolescence and early adulthood, I’ve seen plenty of 19, 20, 21 year old people who are just absolute messes because they have no sense of responsibility to themselves and the people around them. Perhaps this won’t come across cultural differences but basically what I’m trying to say is have a discipline to your life as you enter your early adulthood. This is the period where you’re most vulnerable to go astray, have a vision for yourself, and strive towards that vision singularly. Understand yourself, associate with the right kind of people and learn to be responsible to others, but most importantly to yourself. Then ten years later, hopefully you’ll be able to look back at your track record with positivity.

Sex Ed. This should be pretty self-explanatory but for those of you who were forced to go to religious schools like me or simply attend a school that doesnt tell you jackshit about how the hell to slip a condom on then this is for you. Consent. Oh lord I cannot stress this enough. I know so many people my age who have been in these situations, myself included, because they or someone they were with just didnt know or in most cases, ignored the rules regarding consent. Do not have sex with someone who says no or cannot physically give you consent over their body.If you’re going to have sex, make sure to use a condom. This isn't just to stop you from becoming a teen mom (or dad) but also to prevent unwanted STD’s and potential skin infections.Know where to get contraception. I’m not sure about American high schools but here in the England, most high schools and colleges are obliged to provide free contraception at the nurses office or at the front desk. However, if you attend a catholic school then you’ll need to find your “methods” elsewhere at local walk-in centres or a place called “Connect”, a centre for young people found all over England.Cooking & Cleaning. I was lucky to be taught these skills as I was growing up, but so many young people out there dont even know how to something as simple as boiling an egg or ironing a shirt because their parents never ask for their help with household chores. Seriously it doesn't take long to watch a youtube video on how to cook something or ask for help with laundry. Your parents wont be able to mollycoddle you forever. Managing money. When I was 17, I used to spend my wages the day I got them on the most ridiculous stuff. One example of this is the time I spent £80 on a kaneki costume I never even wore plus various other cosplay attire that probably added up to nearly £200 in total. Damn I wish I could go back and slap the hell out of my weeb ass for wasting so much money on pointless things. I get it, that new manga collection may look enticing but saving your leftover money will give you the opportunity to buy a new car, go on holiday with friends etc. You will definitely thank yourself in the long run. Time management. I think its pretty obvious what I’m going to say here but I’ll go ahead and say it anyway. If you have an exam within the next week, do not procrastinate to the point where you have no time left just because you know you’ll pass. Honestly, the amount of times I didn't study because I knew I would manage to scrape through was awful. I took advantage of my natural intelligence instead of enhancing it to achieve higher grades and ended up leaving with a C in maths instead of the B I wanted. I know everyone is different so just remember this one thing, studying pays off. That should hopefully motivate you to study to the best of your ability. And lastly the most important one in my opinion. Always be honest. Now this can range from various different things from not wanting to continue a relationship, opening up to someone about mental issues etc. Yeah its hard breaking up with someone, but if you arent happy being in the relationship then get the hell out of there. As for mental issues, that's also a tough one and I do understand how it feels, but the longer you leave something like that the worst it gets so please do yourself a favour and see that therapist who hangs around school.
